formal: Use formal, professional language. Begin with a polite salutation (e.g., 'Hi [Name],'). Keep sentences clear, complete, and courteous. Avoid contractions (e.g., use 'do not' instead of 'don't'). End with a professional closing such as 'Best regards,' or 'Sincerely,'. Example: 'Hi Emma, I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to invite you to our upcoming meeting. Please confirm your availability. Best regards, Shankar.'
casual: Use friendly, conversational language. You may use contractions (e.g., 'you're', 'can't') and informal greetings like 'Dear [Name]!' or 'Hey [Name]!'. Keep it approachable and easy to read, while still polite. End with casual closings like 'Cheers,' or 'Thanks,'. Example: 'Hey Emma! Hope you're doing well. I wanted to invite you to our Secret Santa party at my place on Friday. Let me know if you can make it! Cheers, Shankar.'
assertive: Use direct, confident, and action-oriented language while remaining polite. Focus on clear instructions or requests. Start directly with the recipient's name or a concise greeting, and be firm but professional. End with a strong, clear closing such as 'Best regards,' or 'Thank you,'. Example: 'Emma, You are invited to the Secret Santa party on Friday at 7 PM. Please confirm your attendance by Wednesday. Best regards, Shankar.'
